an4.196:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
an4.196:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

an4.196:1.2.pli: Atha kho sāḷho ca licchavi abhayo ca licchavi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sāḷho licchavi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.196:1.2.eng: Then Sāḷha and Abhaya the Licchavis went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an4.196:2.1.pli: “Santi, bhante, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā dvayena oghassa nittharaṇaṃ paññapenti—
an4.196:2.1.eng: “There are, sir, some ascetics and brahmins who advocate crossing the flood by means of two things:

an4.196:2.2.eng: purification of ethics, and mortification in disgust of sin.

an4.196:2.3.eng: What does the Buddha say about this?”

an4.196:3.1.pli: “Sīlavisuddhiṃ kho ahaṃ, sāḷha, aññataraṃ sāmaññaṅganti vadāmi.
an4.196:3.1.eng: “Sāḷha, purification of ethics is one of the factors of the ascetic life, I say.

an4.196:3.2.pli: Ye te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā tapojigucchāvādā tapojigucchāsārā tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, abhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
an4.196:3.2.eng: But those ascetics and brahmins who teach fervent mortification in disgust of sin—regarding it as essential and sticking to it—are incapable of crossing the flood.

an4.196:3.3.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparisuddhakāyasamācārā aparisuddhavacīsamācārā aparisuddhamanosamācārā aparisuddhājīvā, abhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
an4.196:3.3.eng: And those ascetics and brahmins whose livelihood and behavior by way of body, speech, and mind, is not pure are also incapable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

an4.196:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, puriso nadiṃ taritukāmo tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
an4.196:4.1.eng: Suppose a man who wanted to cross a river took a sharp axe into a wood.

an4.196:4.2.pli: So tattha passeyya mahatiṃ sālalaṭṭhiṃ ujuṃ navaṃ akukkuccakajātaṃ.
an4.196:4.2.eng: There he’d see a large green sal tree, straight and young and grown unskewed.

an4.196:4.3.eng: He’d cut it down at the base,

an4.196:4.5.eng: and completely strip off the branches and foliage.

an4.196:4.6.eng: Then he’d trim it with axes and

an4.196:4.9.eng: and sand it with a rock.

an4.196:4.10.eng: Finally, he’d launch out on the river.

an4.196:5.2.pli: bhabbo nu kho so puriso nadiṃ taritun”ti?
an4.196:5.2.eng: Is that man capable of crossing the river?”

an4.196:5.5.pli: “Asu hi, bhante, sālalaṭṭhi bahiddhā suparikammakatā anto avisuddhā.
an4.196:5.5.eng: Because that green sal tree is well worked on the outside, but inside it’s still not cleared out.

an4.196:5.6.pli: Tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—sālalaṭṭhi saṃsīdissati, puriso anayabyasanaṃ āpajjissatī”ti.
an4.196:5.6.eng: I’d expect that green sal tree to sink, and the man to come to ruin.”

an4.196:6.1.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā tapojigucchāvādā tapojigucchāsārā tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, abhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
an4.196:6.1.eng: “In the same way, Sāḷha, those ascetics and brahmins who teach fervent mortification in disgust of sin—regarding it as essential and sticking to it—are incapable of crossing the flood.

an4.196:6.2.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā aparisuddhakāyasamācārā aparisuddhavacīsamācārā aparisuddhamanosamācārā aparisuddhājīvā, abhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
an4.196:6.2.eng: And those ascetics and brahmins whose livelihood and behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is not pure are also incapable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

an4.196:7.1.pli: Ye ca kho te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā na tapojigucchāvādā na tapojigucchāsārā na tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, bhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
an4.196:7.1.eng: But those ascetics and brahmins who don’t teach mortification in disgust of sin—not regarding it as essential or sticking to it—are capable of crossing the flood.

an4.196:7.2.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā parisuddhakāyasamācārā parisuddhavacīsamācārā parisuddhamanosamācārā parisuddhājīvā, bhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
an4.196:7.2.eng: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is pure are also capable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

an4.196:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, puriso nadiṃ taritukāmo tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
an4.196:8.1.eng: Suppose a man who wanted to cross a river took a sharp axe into a wood.

an4.196:8.2.pli: So tattha passeyya mahatiṃ sālalaṭṭhiṃ ujuṃ navaṃ akukkuccakajātaṃ.
an4.196:8.2.eng: There he’d see a large green sal tree, straight and young and grown unskewed.

an4.196:8.3.eng: He’d cut it down at the base,

an4.196:8.5.eng: and completely strip off the branches and foliage.

an4.196:8.6.eng: Then he’d trim it with axes and

an4.196:8.8.pli: vāsīhi tacchetvā nikhādanaṃ ādāya anto suvisodhitaṃ visodheyya;
an4.196:8.8.eng: Then he’d take a chisel and completely clear it out inside.

an4.196:8.11.eng: and make it into a boat.

an4.196:8.12.eng: Finally he’d fix it with oars and rudder,

an4.196:8.13.eng: and launch out on the river.

an4.196:9.2.pli: bhabbo nu kho so puriso nadiṃ taritun”ti?
an4.196:9.2.eng: Is that man capable of crossing the river?”

an4.196:9.5.pli: “Asu hi, bhante, sālalaṭṭhi bahiddhā suparikammakatā, anto suvisuddhā nāvākatā phiyārittabaddhā.
an4.196:9.5.eng: Because that green sal tree is well worked on the outside, cleared out on the inside, made into a boat, and fixed with oars and rudder.

an4.196:9.7.pli: ‘nāvā na saṃsīdissati, puriso sotthinā pāraṃ gamissatī’”ti.
an4.196:9.7.eng: that boat to not sink, and the man to safely make it to the far shore.”

an4.196:10.1.pli: “Evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā na tapojigucchāvādā na tapojigucchāsārā na tapojigucchāallīnā viharanti, bhabbā te oghassa nittharaṇāya.
an4.196:10.1.eng: “In the same way, Sāḷha, those ascetics and brahmins who don’t teach fervent mortification in disgust of sin—not regarding it as essential or sticking to it—are capable of crossing the flood.

an4.196:10.2.pli: Yepi te, sāḷha, samaṇabrāhmaṇā parisuddhakāyasamācārā parisuddhavacīsamācārā parisuddhamanosamācārā parisuddhājīvā, bhabbā te ñāṇadassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
an4.196:10.2.eng: And those ascetics and brahmins whose behavior by way of body, speech, and mind is pure are also capable of knowing and seeing, of supreme awakening.

an4.196:10.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, yodhājīvo bahūni cepi kaṇḍacitrakāni jānāti;
an4.196:10.3.eng: Suppose there was a warrior who knew lots of fancy archery tricks.

an4.196:10.4.pli: atha kho so tīhi ṭhānehi rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an4.196:10.4.eng: It is only with these three factors that he becomes worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is reckoned a factor of kingship.

an4.196:10.6.pli: Dūrepātī ca, akkhaṇavedhī ca, mahato ca kāyassa padāletā.
an4.196:10.6.eng: He’s a long-distance shooter, a marksman, and one who shatters large objects.

an4.196:11.1.eng: Just as a warrior is a long-distance shooter,

an4.196:11.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ariyasāvako sammāsamādhi hoti.
an4.196:11.2.eng: a noble disciple has right immersion.

an4.196:11.3.pli: Sammāsamādhi, sāḷha, ariyasāvako yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an4.196:11.3.eng: A noble disciple with right immersion truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.196:11.4.eng: They truly see any kind of feeling …

an4.196:11.7.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an4.196:11.7.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.196:12.1.eng: Just as a warrior is a marksman,

an4.196:12.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ariyasāvako sammādiṭṭhi hoti.
an4.196:12.2.eng: a noble disciple has right view.

an4.196:12.3.pli: Sammādiṭṭhi, sāḷha, ariyasāvako ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an4.196:12.3.eng: A noble disciple with right view truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an4.196:13.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāḷha, yodhājīvo mahato kāyassa padāletā;
an4.196:13.1.eng: Just as a warrior shatters large objects,

an4.196:13.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, sāḷha, ariyasāvako sammāvimutti hoti.
an4.196:13.2.eng: a noble disciple has right freedom.

an4.196:13.3.pli: Sammāvimutti, sāḷha, ariyasāvako mahantaṃ avijjākkhandhaṃ padāletī”ti.
an4.196:13.3.eng: A noble disciple with right freedom shatters the great mass of ignorance.”

an4.197:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an4.197:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an4.197:1.2.pli: Atha kho mallikā devī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho mallikā devī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.197:1.2.eng: Then Queen Mallikā went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an4.197:2.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo dubbaṇṇā ca hoti durūpā supāpikā dassanāya;
an4.197:2.1.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why in this life some ladies are ugly, unattractive, and bad-looking;

an4.197:2.2.pli: daliddā ca hoti appassakā appabhogā appesakkhā ca?
an4.197:2.2.eng: and poor, with few assets and possessions; and insignificant?

an4.197:3.1.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo dubbaṇṇā ca hoti durūpā supāpikā dassanāya;
an4.197:3.1.eng: And why are some ladies ugly, unattractive, and bad-looking;

an4.197:3.2.pli: aḍḍhā ca hoti mahaddhanā mahābhogā mahesakkhā ca?
an4.197:3.2.eng: but rich, affluent, wealthy, and illustrious?

an4.197:4.1.pli: Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo abhirūpā ca hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā;
an4.197:4.1.eng: And why are some ladies attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty;

an4.197:4.2.pli: daliddā ca hoti appassakā appabhogā appesakkhā ca?
an4.197:4.2.eng: but poor, with few assets and possessions; and insignificant?

an4.197:5.1.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo abhirūpā ca hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā, aḍḍhā ca hoti mahaddhanā mahābhogā mahesakkhā cā”ti?
an4.197:5.1.eng: And why are some ladies attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty; and rich, affluent, wealthy, and illustrious?”

an4.197:6.1.pli: “Idha, mallike, ekacco mātugāmo kodhanā hoti upāyāsabahulā.
an4.197:6.1.eng: “Take a lady who is irritable and bad-tempered.

an4.197:6.2.pli: Appampi vuttā samānā abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an4.197:6.2.eng: Even when criticized a little bit she loses her temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an4.197:6.3.pli: Sā na dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an4.197:6.3.eng: She doesn’t give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

an4.197:6.5.eng: envying, resenting, and begrudging the possessions, honor, respect, reverence, homage, and veneration given to others.

an4.197:6.6.pli: Sā ce tato cutā itthattaṃ āgacchati, sā yattha yattha paccājāyati dubbaṇṇā ca hoti durūpā supāpikā dassanāya;
an4.197:6.6.eng: If she comes back to this place after passing away, wherever she is reborn she’s ugly, unattractive, and bad-looking;

an4.197:6.7.pli: daliddā ca hoti appassakā appabhogā appesakkhā ca.
an4.197:6.7.eng: and poor, with few assets and possessions; and insignificant.

an4.197:7.1.pli: Idha pana, mallike, ekacco mātugāmo kodhanā hoti upāyāsabahulā.
an4.197:7.1.eng: Take another lady who is irritable and bad-tempered. …

an4.197:7.2.pli: Appampi vuttā samānā abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.

an4.197:7.3.pli: Sā dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an4.197:7.3.eng: But she does give to ascetics or brahmins …

an4.197:7.5.pli: paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanāsu na issati na upadussati na issaṃ bandhati.

an4.197:7.6.pli: Sā ce tato cutā itthattaṃ āgacchati, sā yattha yattha paccājāyati dubbaṇṇā ca hoti durūpā supāpikā dassanāya;
an4.197:7.6.eng: If she comes back to this place after passing away, wherever she is reborn she’s ugly, unattractive, and bad-looking;

an4.197:7.7.pli: aḍḍhā ca hoti mahaddhanā mahābhogā mahesakkhā ca.
an4.197:7.7.eng: but rich, affluent, wealthy, and illustrious.

an4.197:8.1.pli: Idha pana, mallike, ekacco mātugāmo akkodhanā hoti anupāyāsabahulā.
an4.197:8.1.eng: Take another lady who isn’t irritable and bad-tempered. …

an4.197:8.2.pli: Bahumpi vuttā samānā nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patitthīyati, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.

an4.197:8.3.pli: Sā na dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an4.197:8.3.eng: But she doesn’t give to ascetics or brahmins …

an4.197:8.6.pli: Sā ce tato cutā itthattaṃ āgacchati, sā yattha yattha paccājāyati abhirūpā ca hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā;
an4.197:8.6.eng: If she comes back to this place after passing away, wherever she is reborn she’s attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty;

an4.197:8.7.pli: daliddā ca hoti appassakā appabhogā appesakkhā ca.
an4.197:8.7.eng: but poor, with few assets and possessions; and insignificant.

an4.197:9.1.pli: Idha pana, mallike, ekacco mātugāmo akkodhanā hoti anupāyāsabahulā.
an4.197:9.1.eng: Take another lady who isn’t irritable and bad-tempered. …

an4.197:9.2.pli: Bahumpi vuttā samānā nābhisajjati na kuppati na byāpajjati na patitthīyati, na kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.

an4.197:9.3.pli: Sā dātā hoti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an4.197:9.3.eng: She gives to ascetics and brahmins …

an4.197:9.5.pli: paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanāsu na issati na upadussati na issaṃ bandhati.

an4.197:9.6.pli: Sā ce tato cutā itthattaṃ āgacchati, sā yattha yattha paccājāyati abhirūpā ca hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā;
an4.197:9.6.eng: If she comes back to this place after passing away, wherever she is reborn she’s attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty;

an4.197:9.7.pli: aḍḍhā ca hoti mahaddhanā mahābhogā mahesakkhā ca.
an4.197:9.7.eng: and rich, affluent, wealthy, and illustrious.

an4.197:10.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mallike, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo dubbaṇṇā ca hoti durūpā supāpikā dassanāya;
an4.197:10.1.eng: This is why some ladies are ugly …

an4.197:10.2.pli: daliddā ca hoti appassakā appabhogā appesakkhā ca.

an4.197:10.3.pli: Ayaṃ pana, mallike, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo dubbaṇṇā ca hoti durūpā supāpikā dassanāya;

an4.197:10.4.pli: aḍḍhā ca hoti mahaddhanā mahābhogā mahesakkhā ca.

an4.197:10.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mallike, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo abhirūpā ca hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā;

an4.197:10.6.pli: daliddā ca hoti appassakā appabhogā appesakkhā ca.

an4.197:10.7.pli: Ayaṃ pana, mallike, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco mātugāmo abhirūpā ca hoti dassanīyā pāsādikā paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya samannāgatā;

an4.197:10.8.pli: aḍḍhā ca hoti mahaddhanā mahābhogā mahesakkhā cā”ti.

an4.197:11.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, mallikā devī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.197:11.1.eng: When this was said, Queen Mallikā said to the Buddha:

an4.197:11.2.pli: “yā nūnāhaṃ, bhante, aññaṃ jātiṃ kodhanā ahosiṃ upāyāsabahulā,
an4.197:11.2.eng: “Sir, in another life I must have been irritable and bad-tempered.

an4.197:11.3.pli: appampi vuttā samānā abhisajjiṃ kuppiṃ byāpajjiṃ patitthīyiṃ kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsiṃ,
an4.197:11.3.eng: Even when lightly criticized I must have lost my temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an4.197:11.4.pli: sāhaṃ, bhante, etarahi dubbaṇṇā durūpā supāpikā dassanāya.
an4.197:11.4.eng: For now I am ugly, unattractive, and bad-looking.

an4.197:12.1.pli: Yā nūnāhaṃ, bhante, aññaṃ jātiṃ dātā ahosiṃ samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ, sāhaṃ, bhante, etarahi aḍḍhā mahaddhanā mahābhogā.
an4.197:12.1.eng: In another life I must have given to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting. For now I am rich, affluent, and wealthy.

an4.197:13.1.pli: Yā nūnāhaṃ, bhante, aññaṃ jātiṃ anissāmanikā ahosiṃ, paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanāsu na issiṃ na upadussiṃ na issaṃ bandhiṃ, sāhaṃ, bhante, etarahi mahesakkhā.
an4.197:13.1.eng: In another life, I must not have been jealous, envying, resenting, and begrudging the possessions, honor, respect, reverence, homage, and veneration given to others. For now I am illustrious.

an4.197:13.2.pli: Santi kho pana, bhante, imasmiṃ rājakule khattiyakaññāpi brāhmaṇakaññāpi gahapatikaññāpi, tāsāhaṃ issarādhipaccaṃ kāremi.
an4.197:13.2.eng: In this royal court I command maidens of the aristocrats, brahmins, and householders.

an4.197:13.3.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, ajjatagge akkodhanā bhavissāmi anupāyāsabahulā,
an4.197:13.3.eng: So, sir, from this day forth I will not be irritable and bad-tempered.

an4.197:13.4.pli: bahumpi vuttā samānā nābhisajjissāmi na kuppissāmi na byāpajjissāmi na patitthīyissāmi, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca na pātukarissāmi;
an4.197:13.4.eng: Even when heavily criticized I won’t lose my temper, become annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, or display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an4.197:13.5.pli: dassāmi samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an4.197:13.5.eng: I will give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

an4.197:13.6.pli: Anissāmanikā bhavissāmi, paralābhasakkāragarukāramānanavandanapūjanāsu na ississāmi na upadussissāmi na issaṃ bandhissāmi.
an4.197:13.6.eng: I will not be jealous, envying, resenting, and begrudging the possessions, honor, respect, reverence, homage, and veneration given to others.

an4.197:13.7.pli: Abhikkantaṃ, bhante …pe… upāsikaṃ maṃ, bhante, bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an4.197:13.7.eng: Excellent, sir! … From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
